title: الْوَقْف وَالابْتِدَاء
description: Learn about الوقف والابتداء - the rules of pausing and starting in Arabic recitation, including هاء السكت and types of وقف.

notes.title: What is الوقف?
content: الوَقْف is pausing or stopping during recitation or speech. In Arabic, certain changes occur at the pause: tanween becomes sukoon, final vowels may drop, and هاء السكت may be added.
Understanding وقف is essential for proper Quranic recitation and classical Arabic pronunciation.

notes.title: أنواع الوقف
content: الوقف is divided into: وَقْف تَامّ (complete - meaning is complete), وَقْف كَافٍ (sufficient - meaning is mostly complete), وَقْف حَسَن (good - grammatically sound), وَقْف قَبِيح (ugly - breaks meaning).
These categories help reciters know where they can pause without distorting meaning.

examples.english: In the name of × (don't pause here)

notes.title: هاء السكت
content: هَاء السَّكْت is a هاء added at the end of certain words when pausing to preserve the vowel sound. It's added to words ending in a vowel that would be lost.
Common with: مَا الاستفهامية المجرورة (عَمَّهْ، لِمَهْ، بِمَهْ), الأمر من الناقص (قِهْ، عِهْ), and some other forms.

notes.title: الابتداء
content: الابتِدَاء is starting or resuming speech/recitation. One should start from a place that gives complete meaning. Starting from middle of a phrase can distort meaning.
In Quranic recitation, one should not start from a word that gives wrong meaning if taken alone.

examples.arabic: لَا تَبْدَأْ بِـ«لَا إِلَهَ» ثُمَّ تَقِفْ
examples.english: Don't start with 'no god' then stop
Start: 'There is no god but Allah'
Don't start with 'Allah is poor' (out of context)

notes.title: رموز الوقف في المصحف
content: The mushaf contains symbols indicating pause types: ⁠م (وقف لازم - obligatory), ج (وقف جائز - permissible), صلى (الوصل أولى - connection preferred), قلى (الوقف أولى - pause preferred), لا (لا تقف - don't pause).
These help reciters pause at appropriate places.

notes.title: الوقف في التجويد
content: In tajweed, الوقف has specific rules: إِسْكَان (making sukoon), الرَّوْم (slight vowel), الإِشْمَام (lip rounding for dammah). These affect how the final sound is pronounced.
الإسكان is the standard; الروم and الإشمام are optional refinements used by some reciters.

exercises.prompt: الْوَقْفُ الَّذِي يَتِمُّ فِيهِ الْمَعْنَى يُسَمَّى الْوَقْفَ _____
exercises.promptEn: A pause where the meaning is complete is called وقف _____

exercises.prompt: هَاءُ _____ تُضَافُ فِي آخِرِ بَعْضِ الْكَلِمَاتِ عِنْدَ الْوَقْفِ
exercises.promptEn: هاء _____ is added at the end of some words when pausing
The symbol 'م' in the mushaf means _____ pause
_____ is starting to read after a pause

exercises.answer: Pause-marking ha (added at end when pausing)
Ugly pause (distorts meaning, should be avoided)

exercises.prompt: Pause where meaning is mostly complete
